title: Mastering White on White Photography Lighting
summary: Lindsay Adler demonstrates how to photograph white clothing on a white background using one, two, and three-light setups. She explains techniques to maintain texture in the fabric, ensure proper skin tone exposure, and achieve a pure white background without washing out the subject.

steps.action: Set up the first light by bouncing a strobe into the corner of a white room to create a large, soft light source.
Introduce negative fill using black V-Flats on either side of the subject to add definition to the dress edges and separate the subject from the background.
Add a second light focused specifically on the subject's face to balance the exposure between the bright white dress and the skin tone.
steps.tool: Profoto D3 with Beauty Dish + Grid

steps.action: Set up two background lights with small umbrellas on either side to evenly illuminate the background for a pure white look.
Set the main light for the three-light setup using a white beauty dish without a grid for a wider spread to light the subject head-to-toe.
steps.tool: Profoto D3 with White Beauty Dish

key_takeaways: Bouncing a single light creates soft illumination but offers less control over background whiteness.
Negative fill is essential in white-on-white photography to prevent the subject from blending into the background.
A two-light setup allows for 'layering' exposure, letting you expose the dress and face independently.
To achieve a commercially pure white background while retaining subject contrast, a three-light setup with dedicated background lighting is necessary.
